snippet: Kofi Annan, who also represents the Arab League, said that monitors have helped to ease the violations, but that the peace plan is still in jeopardy.
abstract: Kofi Annan offers a gloomy assessment of the ceasefire he brokered between the Syrian government and the country's opposition forces, saying it could be undermined by continued violations. (M)

byline.original: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR; Rick Gladstone contributed reporting from New York, and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Offering a gloomy assessment of the nearly month-old cease-fire in Syria, Kofi Annan, its main architect, said Tuesday that despite some decrease in military assaults, continuing ''serious violations'' could undermine the full peace plan. Mr. Annan, the envoy of both the United Nations and the Arab League, said that the deployment of unarmed cease-fire monitors -- 60 so far, with a full contingent of 300 anticipated by month's end -- had served at least to calm the most blatant violations of the cease-fire.

headline.main: Syria: Peace Plan at Risk, Annan Warns
